title: Shot Glass Ice Cube Tray Cup ...

description.text:
I saw the basic "Shot Glass Ice Cube" part then immediately wondered why only one?  An ice cube tray has several cups to make a bunch of ice cubes ... then I realized that sometimes the freezer gets full of stuff and a big long tray doesn\'t always fit ... so why not make an adjustable tray ??? So I did it like this ... 
When I was young and drinking I always thought a standard "shot glass" was small ... hence these are oval so they give you a little extra fun ... 
YES, that bottom design is on purpose ... so if the cups get stuck in the frost of older refrigerators you can get a fork or knife under the edge and pry it upwards ... 
And yes, this is MakerBotable.  
This is another of many entries to the makezine.com/go/makerbot  contest ...
blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/04/makerbot_giveaway.html

So MakerBot a couple ... if they work well then MakerBot a few dozen and send me some.  
They're simple ... puzzle like interlocking handles to create any length ice cube tray you want.  
You will have to trim the bottoms of two arms square after printing, but otherwise the rest of this should be a straight forward print.  
If you successfully make this with a 3D printer please send me the build-file and machine type so it can be uploaded here for others to use.

comments.text: Hi, I think you need to use a flexible material if banging it upside down on a table doesn't shake the ice cubes free ...

author: SolidWorksMagi

description.text:
New Version Available!!!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:63796 Bed-Leveling allways was a nightmare to me. I payed a lot of attention when I first assembled my printer, i leveled everything, starting with the desk where i built the machine on it.
But i allways had problems once everything was assembled or if everything was fine and i had to move my machine i had to start all over again... So while i could bring it down to a point where i could print "smaller" parts i recently printed parts that needed the WHOLE printbed-area.
So i decided to put a finger on my problem which seemed to bee the 2 Y-Axis Guides not beeing 100% parallel, and to adjust this i designed these replacement for the fixed Smooth-Rod holder.

I made these for my Orca 0.4 but as "ChrisMagno" pointed out these might work for Mendels as well ;)
EDIT: for mendel rotate my parts by 90Â° (assembly-top-view) the screw still pointing down, I suggest to print the whole set so you will have parts that should fit into each other without any problems
Give it some 25 to 40 percent infill (i used 35)
3 Perimeters (Including Shell) Printed mine in PLA at .2mm Layer Height with a .35mm nozzle NO SUPPORT MATERIAL NEEDED (its all in the geometry) cut the holes (8mm) free with a knife and drill if necesseray The Only thing thats a little painfull (but only once) is:
YOU HAVE TO DISSASEMBLE THE Y-CARRIAGE to change the parts
and you WILL HAVE TO REPLACE THE FIXED SMOOTH-ROD HOLDERS AS WELL! But from now on Bed-Leveling should be easy ;) BOM: 2x M3x20 Zylinder-Head Screws (leftovers from the ORCA-KIT)
2x M3 Locknuts 2x Bed-Leveling-Sets (STL files)

DRAT: Unfortunately one of the side supports for the slider on the main
block broke off. The junction is only 2mm, so I think its it's a bit
under engineered at this point unless your printer is absolutely
perfectly calibrated. It's also 5mm too tall above the rod of my modified Prusa
(smooth rods are on top, but bed clearance is only 5mm above the smooth rod and 15mm above the threaded rod),
so the bed will contact. Finally the ends of the hole for the threaded
rod built filled in, so would have to drill them. Otherwise good idea.

description.text:
This is the fractal generator I originally had in mind, not the strange 3D Line Fractal generator I made earlier, which can yield some interesting results in it's own regard, but gets to chaotic in higher recursions. Basically this is a generalization of the infinite cubic fractal, as it is the simplest fractal that can be generated by it, along with endless other possibilities. Some inputs still don't work even tough they should produce a manifold mesh, maybe it is due to rounding errors or there is still a mistake in my script, testing is really hard, as rendering times are very long. The math in this was really tough to figure out, maybe there is a easier or cleaner method of doing this, but it works(in most cases). The results are not exact as OpenSCAD won't allow connecting triangles only by the edges, they have to share a common point and it won't allow triangles with zero area either, so I need to move the two extra points on each side inwards a bit. This deforms the quadrangles slightly, the amount can be adjusted with the precision setting. Anyways, I'm glad this is finished, I loved fractals since I was a kid and this can be used to make a whole lot of them. Also it was a nice challenge.
In mathematical terms this type of fractals are variants of the Koch curve: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koch_snowflake
Edit: simplified logic, more special cases work now.

There are many customizable bracelets on Thingiverse. Here is another! I was inspired by Emmett's Stretchy Bracelet design; I made one and was impressed by how flexible it was, even printed in PLA. With this customizer, you set the basic bracelet dimensions - inner (wrist) diameter, thickness, etc, then fiddle with various settings to control the compound shape of a cutout that is stamped out of the periphery to form the "ruffle". These bracelets get their flexibility from packing many folds into a small band - a bit of flex in each corner adds up. Output is a solid model intended to be printed with no infill and no top or bottom layers. Warning: the customizer does not prevent you from creating unprintable designs, so be careful to avoid floating fragments or intersecting ruffle patterns.
I printed the rufflebracelet-1.stl sample in brown PLA on my Printrbot Simple and gave it to a friend for her birthday. 0.15 mm layer height, no top or bottom layers, no infill.

I scaled it by 2x and sliced it into a bunch of more easily printable pieces (should be good with no supports). I have only been able to have the three head pieces printed so far. Super-glue worked well, but sticks fast so be careful.

author: Pacca

description.text:
Converted my Mini-Z MR-01 to brushless motor.  
I'm using HobbyKing's S2030-6570 Brushless Inrunner 6560kv.  I only had a 13T pinion which made the car really slow at acceleration. I really need something lower like 7T or 8T.

Used OpenScad to model. I used Slic3r with:
  • 4mm nozzle
  • 60mm travels
  • 2mm layer height
  • no support material

comments.text: Did you ever convert this to a brushless?  Are you interested in some more Mini-z ideas?
comments.author: ByebyeRacing

comments.text: Hi.  I did end up getting it running brushless, however it was not as exciting as I had planned :-(
comments.author: ByebyeRacing

description.text:
Hi everyone This week my students from Computing in the Creative Arts had a public exhibit of their term projects. This project is close to my heart as I worked closely with this particular group of students who had very little technical background (one from film, one from drama, and one from comp.sci, all 2nd year students) but were deeply passionate about creating an interactive robot capable of expressing emotions and interacting with people. (The students involved were Lauren Abramsky, Kristy Titanic and Jesse Shaw, I will link to their websites at a later time) Watch it working:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BqIDKVA1GFA (my students edited video) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cB8393kkLGA (record/playback) In this version, the quadruped has 4 prerecorded states ("angry","party","confused","breathe"), triggered by the touch of a person in areas specified by the eyebrows and a tattoo that read "Mom", painted with bare conductive and used as capacitive sensors.

• Parts List
    • 1x Power Distribution Board (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__38913__Hobb... 1x Arduino Mega (robotshop, adafruit, sparkfun, ...) 8x Analog Feedback Servos (adafruit) 1x Zippy Flightmax 1000mAh 15C (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__19903__Zipp... 1x Bare Conductive Pen (Adafruit) 3x 10M Ohm Resistors 3x PushButtons 4x RGB Leds

• 3D Printed Parts
    Screen Shot 2014-04-05 at 2.48.16 PM.png
    All parts were printed on a replicator 2x. To assemble the robot you will need:
    • 4x servo_mounts_body.stl 1x frame.stl 8x hand_arms_mounts.stl 1x head_alone.stl 4x hand.stl 4x arm.stl Alternatively, you can print the parts in 2 runs (rep2x tray size) 1x body.stl 1x head.stl (If anyone needs .ai, .cdr, shoot me a message and I will upload them ASAP) Arduino code here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/vq7j245edorlk0y/robot.ino In its current state, 2 separate sketches are used, one for pre-recorded motions, one for recording motions (I will upload the second at a later time as well as a single code as soon as i have time to work on this)

comments.text: the hand arm mounts are all the files tougher and will not fit on smaller printers that have 200mm x 200mm printers. it would fit if you did not put all the files in that file
comments.author: jakeyoda

comments.text: Awesome project! It's funny, because I was actually thinking about designing a very similar hexapod last right with emotions and what not.

description.text: Per Cymon's suggestion (comments, parent work), split each in half (was that the correct half to cut?) leaving four identical parts, not just two.

comments.author: AndyP

comments.text: Finally printed one. Had to change filament midway through which made for a neat effect but now I'm afraid it'll give away the solution due to the way it prints. Maybe take the 4 and stand them up on their triangular end so obfuscate the solution?
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: That's funny! My thought was, "bummer, I wished I'd made this about 50% larger."
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Yup, that's the way. I remember them sitting on a desk in pyramid mode well enough. I'll have to print this out to try.

comments.text: It's definitely friction-dependent. The slick fresh-printed ABS on my melamine desktop isn't doing it. But on a piece of MDF it's staying in the pyramid acceptably well.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I was having lunch today with a friend and we were talking about your 4 piece puzzle idea.  I told him I'd try it, but you beat me to it.

comments.text: Ah... that slicing does make it more pocketable, in that it's thinner. My pieces are chunky and pointy, could hurt a leg! But both options actually produce a cluster of four identical parts, so as long as you don't mix parts from the different approaches... or at least ensure you have two of one and two of the other... you're good to go.

remixed_from.author: wildBill83
remixed_from.title: wildBill's PG35L Direct Drive Extruder V1.1

description.text:
This is a remix of Wild Bill's PG35l extruder design. I really like the extruder design, but I had problems with the PG35l motor. I wanted to adapt the design to use a geared nema 11 motor. So for works pretty great and the retraction is great at high acceleration. Utilizes a 27:1 ratio motor from phidgets.com here: http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?category=23&product_id=3321_0.
The idler is the same as the one in Wild Bill's design. If you have any questions please let me know. This extruder utilizes the hot end fan mount designed by Mike P. for his Delta-Pi printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53708

Print out the extruder body with support. You will need for hardware:
1 x MK 7 or equivalent drive gear
2x 50 mm M3 Screws
2 x Springs
4 x M3 washers
2 x M3 Nuts
2 M4 Nuts
2 x 20-25 mm M4 Nuts (Depends on your mount)
3 x 20mm M3 screws
1 x 608 Bearing
1 x 8 mm section to hold 608 bearing

comments.text: How fast can you print with it? What stepper driver are you using?

comments.text:
Nice design, but it has a mistake (as of October 5,2012), if you want the dice to have the standard arrangement of spots. On standard dice, opposite faces always add up to 7. They don't do this in your design.
For a clear explanation, see: Â http://homepage.ntlworld.com/dice-play/DiceStandard.htmhttp://homepage.ntlworld.com/d...Â

title: Printrbot Plus v2.1 Bowden extruder mod

description.text:
My version of a bowden extruder for my Printrbot Plus v2.1. I wanted the extruder motor to mount to the right side of the X axis assembly, opposite the X motor to balance the weight. The LED mount is for 5 LEDs I salvaged from a tap light, use the cover to block the slot if you don't want a light. The hotend mount and fan mount are in 2 pieces for easier printing and slide together. Purchased parts list:
Push To Connect Straight Male Fitting 4 mm OD, 1/4" NPT Thread - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007FD53RU/ref=oh_details_o05_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1/4"-18npt tap - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000GAV8YG/ref=oh_details_o04_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
2.0 mm ID PTFE Teflon Tube for 1.75 mm Filament RepRap-DIY 3D Printer Parts - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C45208O/ref=oh_details_o07_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Update 6/13/2014 - This mod work, but the PTFE fitting let the tube twist, causing the quick grip teeth to cut a grove around the tube. The groove made it hard to pull the tube out and would, eventually, cut through the tube and cause it to break off. Solution is to stay away from quick grip fittings or turn the feed motor 90 degrees so the tube is not twisting in the fitting. Bottom line, I cannot print faster because the material layers seperat at higher speeds, so I abandoned the Bowden and went back to the original setup.

remixed_from.author: fbuenonet
remixed_from.title: Smartrap Mini - Improvements in the X and Y axis

description.text: I have made some minor modifications based on the 4.6 version of the Smartrap, mainly the GT2 belt & pulley.  This is a work in progress so I will be refining it as time allows.  Unfortunately this upgrade requires both Z608 (x3) and Z625 (x2) bearings.  I wanted to keep them all the same, but it is what it is for now.

For the Y axis, all you need to do is print 2x of the lm8_holder_y_GT2.stl and 2 Z608_bearing_cap.stl.  I secured the 2 ends of the belts with zip ties.  No need to get fancy here.  
For the X axis, you have a couple of options.  If you have not started printing parts for your Smartrap, go ahead and print the plate_x_GT2.stl.  If you already have this part, you can reprint the plate, or you can just print the Z608_bearing_holder_RevA.stl and fit it where the endstop would go.  As you can see from the pictures, I decided to move the end stop to the end of the carriage and attach it to the X_end_with_endstop.stl.  You'll also need to print the Z625_bearing_holder.stl and Z625_bearing_cap.stl to mount at the rear.  I went with Z625 bearings because there just isn't enough clearance for the Z608 bearings due to the lm8_X_holder piece.  
If you have any questions or if anything does not make sense, please let me know.  
Enjoy.

comments.text: How do you connect the belt to the ends? Mine's slipping and just doesn't look right.
comments.author: BradStaff

comments.text:
Ya, both side. It's too close to GT2 pulley & it also hit the endstop.
Maybe my plate_base too small?
comments.author: cyberbsd

comments.text: Which base plate version did you print?  I can see it rubbing against the pulley gear perhaps but it shouldn't protrude out into the end stop area.
comments.author: cyberbsd

comments.text:
I noticed it's much narrower
https://github.com/smartfriendz/smartrap/commits/master/stl/release/lm8_holder_y.stlhttps://github.com/smartfriend...
comments.author: evannguyen

comments.text: By large do you mean it's hitting the GT2 pulley?  I realized that depending on where you source your pulley that might be an issue. I could put a recess or cut out there to avoid that issue.
comments.author: evannguyen

comments.text: lm8_holder_y_gt2 might be a little too large on y direction.
comments.author: cyberbsd

comments.text: hi, what belt pulleys do you use, how many teeth on the pulley gear?
comments.author: cae2100

comments.text: I use 6mm wide 2mm pitch belt and 20 teeth drive gear.  You can also use 16 teeth drive gear if you wish.  The E values for X and Y when you switch to the GT2 are equal 80.  You'll have to change that in the firmware and/or EEPROM or else your calibration/scaling will be out of whack.
comments.author: cae2100

comments.text: oh, ok, ty for the reply
comments.author: evannguyen

comments.text:
Very nice work :)
You both did a good job with the belt system. I will really integrate holes on the net version (more easy to integrate this option).
Maybe also i will enlarge X axis.. It's really too tight to make anything different up there :)
comments.author: smartfriendz

comments.text: I have the MK7 drive gear and it works fine using 2mm tube.  I think the location of the integrated extruder also plays into it as well.  If the tube bends too much it will take more torque to drive the filament. I moved the extruder outside of the base setup to help keep the tube bend to a minimum and it has been working pretty good.
comments.author: smartfriendz

comments.text:
ha. that's a very good idea. I didn't think about that ! silly.
I will do some tests with less bended bowden ( maybe i make it too small in fact) .
thank you !
comments.author: evannguyen

comments.text:
Hi!
I see you've decided to experiment with the changes I made to the original Smartrap. I hope you've improved your performance and you get good results.
I have many problems with extrusion. They may be the hotend. So far I have tried several and I do not get good results. The filament bounces on the nozzle as if the engine does not have enough strength to push.
I'm still doing tests, both as component configurations and hopefully find the right solution, because I like good design of this printer.
Good luck.
comments.author: fbuenonet

comments.text: You can see in my picture that I did not use the extruder setup from smartrap.  It did not work well for me because the bearing is stationary.  Any time you have a change in filament diameter, you're going to have problems.  For now I've pulled the extruder motor out and I'm running a different extruder setup.  The things to do on my list are:

author: bobunobu

description.text: This is a rough approximation of Cincinnati's Roebling Suspension Bridge.

Print two roebling_3_120820c_truss.stl and four roebling_3_120821c_side.stl pieces.
First glue the sides to the truss parts with acetone or your favorite glue.
File one end of each bridge section perpendicular (square) to the bridge section.
Glue the filed ends together
